I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2007 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) to 
prepare a road development project in Heilongjiang Province.1 ADB’s Fact-Finding Mission 
visited the project site in June 2008. It (i) carried out an initial poverty and social analysis (IPSA) 
and  rapid  environmental  assessment,  (ii)  held  consultation  meetings,  and  (iii)  collected 
necessary data and information. This report is based on the understanding reached with the 
Government on the objective, scope, costs, financing, terms of reference, and implementation 
arrangements for the TA, and the Mission’s observations in the field.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Recognizing the need for rapid development of the transport sector to meet the demands 
of high economic growth, the Government of the PRC has been investing heavily in transport 
infrastructure and services over the last 2 decades. Since 1990, the demand for passenger 
transport has grown at an annual average rate of 7.8%, and that for freight transport at 7.6%. 
This growth led to an increase in the modal share of roads, particularly for passenger traffic. By 
2006, road transport carried 52.8% of passenger traffic and 11.1% of freight traffic. 
 
3.  To address the major road infrastructure needs, the Government has launched several 
initiatives—the national trunk highway system (1992), the western region development plan 
(1998), and the grand plan for revitalizing the northeast region (2003). A renewed national 
expressway  development  plan—the  7918  national  expressway  network—consists  of 
constructing seven links to Beijing, nine north–south corridors, and 18 east–west corridors 
totaling 85,000 kilometers (km) of expressways and high-class highways by 2020. The national 
expressway network is expected to reach more than 1 billion people by connecting all provincial 
capitals and large urban centers of more than 500,000 people with cities of more than 200,000 
people. In addition, in 2005, the Rural Roads Construction Program2 under the 11th Five-Year 
Plan 2006–2010 was approved to address the issues of lagging rural development and widening 
rural–urban income disparities by investing CNY800 billion. The 11th Five-Year Plan aims to 
connect all townships and villages by all-weather roads, and 90% of townships and 80% of 
villages by paved roads. The regional targets for paved roads are to connect all townships and 
villages in the east; 88% in central provinces; and 90% of townships and 50% of villages in the 
west.  
 
4.  By the end of 2006, the total road network in the PRC had grown to 3.46 million km, 
consisting of 45,300 km of expressways, 45,300 km of class I roads, 262,700 km of class II 
roads, 354,700 km of class III roads, 1,574,800 km of class IV roads, and 1,174,100 km of 
unclassified  roads.  At  present,  100%  of  counties,  98.3%  of  townships,  and  86.4%  of 
administrative villages are accessible by road. In 2006, Heilongjiang had a road network of 
139,335 km, of which 6.8% comprised high-class highways: 958 km of expressways, 1,325 km 
of class I highways, and 7,279 km of class II highways. Heilongjiang’s road density in 2006 was 
30.7 km per 100 km2. 
 
5.  Heilongjiang is a landlocked province and has no direct access to ocean ports except by 
long routes through other provinces or the Russian Federation. It is in the extreme north of the 
PRC and is bordered by the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (Inner Mongolia) on the west, 
the Russian Federation on the north and east, and Jilin Province on the south. Its area of

454,000 km2 makes it the 6th largest province in the country. It has fertile land and abundant 
natural resources. About 42% of its land is forestland, and cultivated land covers 9.2 million 
hectares, which is the largest in the country. Its population was 38.2 million in 2006 and per 
capita gross domestic product (GDP) was CNY16,195. The province was an industrial base 
before  the  1980s;  its  main  sectors  are  petroleum,  coal,  power  plant  equipment,  heavy 
machinery, steel, timber, and woodworking. The industry share of GDP is 12% for primary, 54% 
for secondary, and 34% for tertiary industries. Foreign trade is vital to Heilongjiang’s economy; 
international  and  domestic  demand  for  its  products  has  consistently  risen.  The  common 
boundary of Heilongjiang and the Russian Federation is 3,400 km long with 14 class I ports. In 
2007, total trade with the Russian Federation was 20% of that of the whole PRC, and the total 
value of goods traded comprised about 16.6% of the province’s GDP. Foreign trade has grown 
by more than 15% per annum over the last 5 years.  
 
6.  Despite its economic potential, however, Heilongjiang has been left behind by the fast- 
developing coastal provinces since the 1980s. In support of the grand plan to revitalize the 
northeast region as an industrial hub, the Ministry of Transport3 approved in 2006 the northeast 
regional transport network development plan involving three provinces.4 In line with the plan, the 
Heilongjiang Road Network Plan for 2006–2020 was developed by the Heilongjiang Provincial 
Communications  Department  (HPCD)  in  2006,  with  the  aim  of  building  the  2763  network 
comprising two rings, seven radial, six north–south, and three west–east high-class highways 
totaling 13,000 km. As of the end of 2007, 16% of this plan had been achieved.  
 
7.  The 824 km Qiangfeng Farm–Nenjiang (WE2) road is one of the three key west–east 
corridors of the 2763 network and is a major route connecting the Sanjiang Plain agricultural 
area, and coal mines and wood industry in the northeast and Songnen Plain farm, pastoral area, 
and  Wudalianchi  GeoPark5  in  the  northwest.  Along  WE2  are  five  road  sections  totaling 
377.6 km, which either are in poor condition or need to be constructed. Xing’an Mountain 
prevents direct travel between the northeastern and northwestern parts of the province and 
between Yichun and Bei’an counties. To go to the northeast, goods and passengers from 
counties in the northwest travel on the existing north–south roads to Harbin or Suihua before 
moving northeast. The long detour or lengthy travel time significantly hinders the province’s 
economic development. The remaining part of WE2 is class II concrete road in good condition.  
An improved Qiangfeng Farm–Nenjiang corridor—which eventually reaches Mongolia, an ADB 
CAREC country6—will provide the shortest and important trade link between Inner Mongolia on 
the northwest and Fuyuan port on the border with the Russian Federation in the northeast via an 
existing 86 km class II concrete road. Fuyuan is a national land port opened in 1993 and is only 
63 km away from Khabarovsk City in the Russian Far East. Fuyuan had a trade volume of 
385,000 tons valued at CNY2.4 billion in 2006, and has potential to grow in the foreseeable 
future.  
 
8.  The proposed Project (see Map) represents the fourth ADB-financed road project in 
Heilongjiang.  The  first  two  projects7  have  been  successfully  completed  while  the  third

3
project8 is being implemented satisfactorily. The Project will construct 363.4 km of provincial 
expressway or high-class highway that forms part of the Qiangfeng Farm–Nenjiang corridor 
(WE2). The Project will (i) construct a 175 km access-controlled four-lane expressway—the 
missing  link  between  Yichun  and  Bei’an—with  a  designed  speed  of  80–100  km  per  hour 
depending on the terrain, (ii) build a 60 km expressway with a designed speed of 100 km per 
hour between Bei’an and Wudulianchi along the existing class II highway, (iii) upgrade to a two-
lane class II highway a 110 km gravel road section between Wudulianchi and Nenjiang, and 
(iv) construct a 18.4 km class I highway including a bridge across the Nen River—the missing 
link between Nenjiang and the border with Inner Mongolia. The Government has committed to 
utilize its own fund to construct a 14.2 km class I highway—the remaining missing link between 
Fujin and Suibin, including an extra-large bridge across the Songhua River concurrent with the 
Project. HPCD has also agreed that Heilongjiang will construct a bridge across Nen River under 
the Project while Inner Mongolia will build a 146 km class I road from Nen Bridge to Jiagedaqi 
City in Inner Mongolia using its own funds at the same time as the Project.   
 
9.  The project road will connect to the one vertical line, two radial lines of the 2763 network 
that is vital to Heilongjiang and the northeast region as it will enhance Heilongjiang’s road 
network efficiency. The Project will establish resource-efficient transport. The travel distance 
from Yichun to Nenjiang will be shorter by about 200 km and the time reduced by 6 hours. At 
present, there is no road between Yichun and Bei’an; thus passenger and freight traffic travel on 
the north–south Yichun–Suihua and Bei’an–Suihua roads, making up a traffic volume of 4,658 
and  5,377  vehicles  per  day,  respectively.  The  existing  class  II  road  between  Bei’an  and 
Wudulianchi had a traffic volume of 6,719 vehicles per day in 2007 which had grown at more 
than 11% annually in the past 5 years. Wudulianchi GeoPark has high potential for tourism 
development; it received 0.7 million tourists in 2007. Overall, traffic in the project roads will grow 
by 9%–10% during 2011–2020 and by 6%–7% during 2021–2030. Road safety is a serious 
issue in Heilongjiang, particularly during the winter season—40% of accidents (3,021 from a 
total of 7,552) is due to ice and snow on roads because of inadequate snow clearance during 
harsh winters. The project road is expected to (i) increase the transport capacity on WE2, 
(ii) substantially reduce fuel consumption and vehicle emissions, and (iii) improve the efficiency 
and safety of the road network in Heilongjiang, thus playing a critical role in catalyzing economic 
growth, spurring interprovincial and regional trade, and reducing poverty in the project area.  
 
10.  The project area covers Yichun, Bei’an, Wudulianchi, and Nenjiang counties or cities in 
Heihe Prefecture in the remote northwestern part of Heilongjiang, and has a population of 
1.43 million, of which 53% is rural. In 2006, the rural per capita income was CNY3,475. The per 
capita GDP in the area was CNY8,223, which is 49% of the provincial average of CNY16,195, 
and 52% of the national average. The project area has numerous poverty villages; the rural 
poverty incidence is about 8%. Long distances and poor transport conditions limit the mobility of 
people in the project area. The Project will substantially improve transport infrastructure and 
service, and will improve access to larger markets and higher quality social services. The main 
ethnic groups in the project area include Manchu, Korean, and Hui. There are no minority 
townships along the alignment, but there are about eight minority villages. The villages have 
mainly Han people; only about 20% are ethnic minorities.  
 
11.  ADB’s operational strategy9 in the road subsector supports (i) construction of roads that 
connect major growth centers supported by a system of local roads; (ii) development and 
improvement of urban transport and rural roads; (iii) promotion of road safety, reduction of

vehicle emissions, and efficient use of energy; (iv) strengthening of institutions to increase the 
commercial orientation and efficiency of expressway organizations; (v) strengthening of regional 
cooperation in transport; (vi) promotion of public–private partnership; and (vii) establishment of 
resource-efficient transport. The proposed Project is consistent with the PRC’s development 
priorities in the central and western parts of the country and in the old industrial areas in the 
northeast, and ADB’s strategy for the transport sector, which focuses on assistance to the less 
developed inland provinces where the majority of the poor live. The ADB Operations Evaluation 
Department evaluated the sector assistance program in 2007 and examined the performance of 
ADB’s assistance in developing roads and railways in the PRC. The assessment concluded that 
ADB’s support for the road sector during 1997–2005 was successful, and suggested giving 
more  attention  to  identifying  value  addition  and  enhancing  the  performance  of  technical 
assistance for future road projects to be financed by ADB. Such recommendations are being 
taken into account in preparing the Project.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The TA will help HPCD develop a more efficient, safe, and environmentally sustainable 
road transport in the project area. The outcome will be a project suitable for ADB financing that 
the Government will agree to. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The initial poverty and social analysis (IPSA) carried out during fact-finding examined 
poverty conditions, minority issues, resettlement effects, gender issues and vulnerable groups 
(Appendix 2). It found that the key social issues to be addressed during project preparation are 
poverty  impact,  resettlement  effects,  and  related  impacts  on  ethnic  minorities.  The  IPSA 
concluded that the Project should be in involuntary resettlement category A, while the presence 
of indigenous people puts it in category B, which may require a full resettlement plan and a 
social development action plan. The TA will assist HPCD in (i) upgrading the feasibility study 
including an environmental impact assessment (EIA) and summary EIA, and a resettlement plan 
to ensure that the Project conforms to ADB requirements; (ii) conducting detailed social impact 
analysis, investigating opportunities to provide more immediate and direct benefits to poor 
people, and incorporating viable options into the Project either as a component or in a social 
development action plan embracing ethnic minorities to enhance their benefits from the Project; 
(iii)  designing  the  project  framework,  identifying  performance  targets  and  indicators  for 
monitoring  socioeconomic  impact,  and  establishing  baseline  values  and  measuring  or 
monitoring mechanisms; (iv) confirming the technical, economic, and financial viability of the 
proposed investment; (v) updating transport demand with due consideration of transport modes 
with low energy consumption and low emission, and producing  a  short  policy  note  for  the 
development of environment-friendly transport mode; (vi) reviewing the road sector issues and 
providing the basis for strengthening the ongoing policy dialogue with the Government in key 
areas, focusing on management of rural road maintenance, rural transport services, regional 
cooperation,  and  interprovincial  connectivity;  (vii)  exploring  ways  of  how  the  project  can 
complement the activities under the Heilongjiang Road Network Development Project in road 
safety, vehicle overloading, vehicle emissions, and private sector participation in the road sector 
(footnote 8); (viii) conducting stakeholder analysis and preparing a consultation and participation 
plan; and (ix) assessing the procurement capacity of HPCD and preparing a draft procurement 
plan for the contract packages that will be needed under the Project.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000, of which the Government has requested ADB 
financing of $600,000 (Appendix 3). ADB will finance the TA with a grant from ADB’s TA funding 
program. The Government will finance the balance equivalent to $100,000 in kind by providing 
counterpart  staff,  office  facilities,  local  transport,  and  other  support  services  required  in 
implementing the TA. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will require 35.5 person-months of consulting services (11.5 international and 24 
national) spread over 4 months, to carry out the work as defined in the terms of reference 
(Appendix  4).  ADB  will  engage  a  consulting  firm  using  the  simplified  technical  proposal 
procedures and quality- and cost-based selection method based on the quality–cost ratio of 
80:20 in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The international consultants will have expertise in (i) highway engineering and 
road  maintenance  management,  (ii)  transport  economics  and  rural  transport  services, 
(iii) financial analysis and expressway operations, (iv) regional development, (v) social and 
poverty analysis, and (vi) environment assessment. Expertise required for national consultants 
will be in (i) civil works and soil engineering; (ii) transport economics; (iii) financial analysis and 
expressway operations; (iv) regional development and trade facilitation; (v) poverty, social and 
gender  analysis;  (vi) environmental  assessment;  (vii)  resettlement  planning;  (viii)  transport 
service; and (ix) contract packaging and procurement planning. 
  
16.  HPCD  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  In  March  2008,  HPCD  established  a  project 
management office with six staff members to coordinate and supervise TA activities, including 
(i) monitoring progress, (ii) resolving issues that arise during implementation, (iii) assisting in 
arranging meetings and workshops, and (iv) liaising with various government agencies and 
organizations.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  will  ensure  coordination  among  the  National 
Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Ministry  of  Transport,  Ministry  of  Environmental 
Protection, Ministry of Land and Resources, HPCD, and other government agencies relevant to 
the TA. HPCD will provide ADB and the consultants with the feasibility study; engineering 
studies; EIA; resettlement plan; and all other materials, recent studies, and reports required to 
implement the TA. Tripartite meetings involving the Government, ADB, and the consultants will 
be held in the PRC to review the consultants’ inception and draft final reports. The consultants 
will procure computer hardware and/or software, photocopier, facsimile machine, and other 
office  equipment  that  they  need  under  the  TA  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement (2007, as amended from time to time), and will turn them over to HPCD after 
completion of the TA. The consultants are expected to be fielded in February 2009; their work 
will be carried out over 4 months and be completed in July 2009 with the submission of the final 
report after comments received from ADB and HPCD in June 2009 have been incorporated. The 
consultants’ final report will be posted on ADB’s website upon TA completion.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  preparing  the  Heilongjiang  Road 
Development II Project (Yichun–Nenjiang), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy and the sector analysis describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy 
of the partner country. 
 
The  transport  sector  contributes  to  poverty  reduction  directly  through  improved  access  to  markets,  employment 
opportunities, and social services; and indirectly by facilitating economic development. The project area is in the remote 
northern part of Heilongjiang, and will complete the highway network that has been partially financed by previous Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) highway projects. The proposed project will reduce the time and cost of travel from west to east, 
thereby help speed up economic development, job creation, and improved access to larger markets and higher quality 
social services. 
 
B.    Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention (GI)   Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The construction of the Yichun–Nenjiang highway  will have indirect impacts on poverty reduction. The Project will 
substantially improve transport infrastructure and service and will facilitate economic development that will provide more 
employment and income-generating opportunities for local people. The Project will also improve access to markets and 
social services for the county centers and towns. Rural poverty incidence in the project area is about 8%.  
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA)/due diligence? 
 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
The Project could directly contribute to poverty reduction in the project area by generating short-term employment 
opportunities in construction, and indirectly through faster economic growth from farming and tourism in the long term. A 
detailed poverty and social analysis will assess poverty incidence in the project area, investigate opportunities to provide 
more immediate and direct benefits to poor people, and incorporate viable options into the Project either as a component or 
in a social development action plan (SDAP) including ethnic minorities to enhance their benefits from the Project. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.    Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
project? 
 
The primary beneficiaries include local government, transport companies, state farms, state forest farms, local businesses, 
and local residents. The 20,000–30,000 poor in 50–100 poverty villages will benefit from the proposed Project (better 
estimates will be made during the PPTA). There are already good roads or planned improvements for local road access to 
villages; therefore, the poverty villages will benefit equally from the highway project.

2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
The beneficiaries require improved transport infrastructure and services to enable goods and people to reach distant 
centers faster and safely. The current road network does not permit convenient east–west movements. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? 
 
There are no major constraints. The north–south roads are good, but the east–west roads are very limited. Local people 
have access to major rural roads and vehicles; however, rural transport services are inadequate. The Project will provide 
(i) improved transport infrastructure to give access to better employment opportunities, larger markets, and higher quality 
social services; and (ii) reliable and convenient bus service.   
 
 
B.    Consultation and Participation 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
Major stakeholders include Heilongjiang Provincial Communications Department, local governments, transport companies, 
state farms, state forest farms, local businesses, and local residents. 
 
2.  What type of consultation and participation is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)? 
 
Stakeholders will be consulted during the preparation of the feasibility study report, environmental impact assessment and 
draft resettlement plan. The ADB PPTA Fact-Finding Mission held initial stakeholder consultation in the affected counties. 
Further consultation will be carried out for the environmental impact assessment, resettlement planning, and poverty and 
social analysis during the PPTA phase.

expressway alignment; (ii) participate in preparing and implementing village-level rehabilitation plans and SDAP if there is 
one, and (iii) be hired for construction of the project highway. 
 
C.    Gender and Development 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector and/or subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project or program? 
 
There are no major gender issues in the project area. Women have no problems concerning access to services. The PPTA 
will investigate opportunities to further enhance the benefits to women (e.g., improved public transport service and local 
road improvements that lead to better access to education, health care, and markets). The resettlement plan and possible 
SDAP will include special measures to mitigate adverse impacts and improve conditions for women, especially improved 
access to education, health facilities, and employment. 
 
2.  Does the proposed project or program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment by 
improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation in decision 
making?       Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
During the PPTA, all potential measures will be identified through consultation and participation, and a project component or 
a SDAP will be prepared to address special measures to improve conditions of women. 
 
3.  Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or widen gender inequality? 
          Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
The Project will cause adverse impacts due to (i) land acquisition and resettlement, which will be addressed in the 
resettlement plan; and (ii) increased risk of communicable diseases, which will be addressed in the SDAP if required. 
Livelihood opportunities and training requirements will be included in the resettlement plan.

35.  Ensure that ADB’s requirements for social analysis and resettlement consultation and 
planning are met.15 Assist HPCD to (i) initiate a C&P process for resettlement; (ii) document the 
C&P process during the TA; and (iii) prepare a C&P plan for resettlement implementation, 
including a format for documenting consultation with affected people and  affected communities, 
local leaders, proponents and other stakeholders. Prepare a resettlement information booklet for 
distribution to all affected villages and households.  
 
H.  Reporting 
 
36.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report 4 weeks after their services start (start 
by 15 February 2009; submit report by 15  March 2009), (ii) an interim report 7 weeks after the 
start (7 April 2009), (iii) a draft final report after 12 weeks (15 May 2009), and (iv) the final report 
after  18  weeks  (by  15  July  2009).  Two  copies  of  each  report  in  the  English  and  Chinese 
languages  are  required  for  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission, Ministry of Transportation, Ministry of Environmental Protection, and HPCD. ADB 
requires three copies of each report in the English language (except the draft final report of which 
five copies are required). ADB’s standard format and style for reports will be used.16 The draft final 
report and the final report will comprise (i) the main volume, following the ADB format for the 
report and recommendation of the President (an executive summary [3 pages], main text [20 
pages] and core appendixes [40 pages]); and (ii) appendix volumes with full details. 
 
 
 
                                                 
15  ADB. 1998. Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice. Manila; ADB. 2006. Strengthening Participation 
for Development Results: A Staff Guide to Consultation and Participation. Manila. 
16 ADB. 2002. Handbook of Style and Usage. Manila.
